name: Elegy for a Dead World
description: Explore dead civilizations, write about what you find, and share your stories with the universe: a game about writing fiction.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP/Vista/7 Processor: Dual Core Memory: 1 GB RAM Graphics: 3D card with 512MB DirectX: Version 9.0c Storage: 2 GB available space

reviews.review_text: As someone who does quite alot of creative writing, I was extremely intrigued by the idea of this 'game'. After giving it a try, I've got to say that whilst the concept is great, in practise it is a huge failure. There is hardly anything to this program! Sure, it's sort of interesting to look at - what there is of it, anyway. But there is nothing there to even remotely justify the relatively hefty price tag. There is hardly any content at all. Very disappointing. Quite frankly, I've received better inspiration for stories whilst sitting at my desk and staring out of my window into the street. Thank goodness I got it included as part of a Humble Bundle - If I'd paid full price for this I would feel REALLY let down.  If you're an aspiring writer, forget this useless program. Get out into the world and look at what is going on around you.

Imagine going to a museum and seeing an enormous, beautiful painting of a long-abandoned alien world, and having a notepad with a few abstract sentences and some fill-in-the-blank mad libs to encourage you. That's essentially what this game is; you stroll through the world, observing, and occasionally are prompted to write something, anything, about it. You also have the option to read what other players have written. I was hoping for more, so my one playthrough (so far) left me feeling unsatisfied; but I seem to be in the minority, because a lot of people have said this helped them. Give it a try! Maybe it will unlock the writer within you?

Elegy for a Dead World is not a game but an interactive tool for writing short fiction. You explore three different worlds while either filling in the blanks of an existing story or writing your own tale from scratch.  The locations themselves are beautiful and the existing story stubs are pretty decent. Unfortunately the game suffers from lack of content. There's only three small worlds to explore and they are all tonally rather similar. Dead worlds filled with the ruins of ancient civilizations.  While I found the idea great, I still wouldn't recommend Elegy for a Dead World. The full price on Steam is extremely high for the limited amount of content you get. And besides, at least for me it wasn't even that good as a source of inspiration.  The good: - Interesting concept - Beautiful worlds  The bad: - Limited amount of content - All the locations are rather similar - There are much better sources of inspiration out there

This is a very interesting indie game, there is no goal in this game, but to write a good story satisfactory to your own perspective, followed by good animated art, sound effects and visual effect, it is very fun and easy if you like to create a sci fi story through writing.

Atmospheric, immersive, and prompts the player helpfully to nudge us towards just a bit more creative expression than maybe we'd be otherwise comfortable with... the challenge of writing something meaningful remains of self-imposed difficulty, but in such a beautiful world, it's not difficultt o be inspired.

Preface: This is a very SHORT 'game'. It honestly feels like a preview rather than the whole product. It's also certainly not for everyone. It's geared more towards the type of person who writes long headcanons for their villagers in Banished or create elaborate backstories for their Bioware characters. For people who have used programs like Zen Writer, this gets you into the same kind of simplified mindset-- there's nothing but you, the art, the sound, and the words. You won't get the editing and organizational capabilities of programs like Scrivener, but it's extremely useful for allowing you to write without the distraction of fiddly program features. That said, there's a lot to recommend it to gamers and writers alike.  PROS + Beautiful artwork. Like absolutely stunning. + Great prompts-- just enough to get you thinking if you need them, but without guiding you too much + Export option-- love the ability to export your stories, though only as HTML  CONS - Too short! Needs many more worlds, with more complexity - No spell check - Space available for writing is limited to 1000 characters per prompt-- definitely not enough when you're on a roll! - No ability to export as a simple word or txt document - Atmospheric sounds are good, but repetitive (and loud!)  What I would dearly love is a game that expands on the worlds available by tenfold, and that gives a more comprehensive writing program with adjustable capabilities.  SUGGESTIONS (just in case the devs ever want to expand or someone wants to make a similar program)  * Add a lot more worlds * Spell check during edit mode * Quick access to each prompt area on a world from the end menu, with short previews of each prompt text (so that users don't have to read through each area chronologically to find where they want to edit). * Include a manual save option so that we can simply press, say, f11 to save without closing the prompt box * Unlock the word limit for each prompt area * Allow users to import music from their hard drive into a 'writing playlist' (like Zen Writer) to use when they don't want to listen to the in-game music/sounds. * On-Screen volume control * Export to text document option

This game seems that it is not out of the beta phase. Not worth full price and it also seems that game development is dead for this game, Like most reviews of this game say this game has so much potential to become something big, but unfortunately we will most likely not get anything else out of it.

Interesting experience for aspiring authors.  This program offers a backgroundworld in images and optionally spots to write something with the start of a sentence. When reaching the 'end', you get the option to export your story with a (admittedly small) slice of the background of that spot.

Ok, to start off: I had really high expectations from the game. The majority of the reviews are extremely positive, and I love to write. If my expectations were a bit too high, well.. Sorry.   Actual Gameplay: Lacking. Honestly, I was extremely excited when I first saw this. I started it up, and saw an impressive starting point. It seemed as though I was floating around in a nebula, with a jetpack to propel me where I wanted to go. 'Whoa.' Was pretty much my first thought. Then I jumped into a wormhole/portal and got down to the writing part. It turns out, it just shows you a 3D-ish landscape in which you can move forwards and backwards. Around the place are little 'Prompts' that start you off with a few words. You are supposed to continue on from these promts, or if you are unhappy with what they said, you can change it. Personally, I found that it felt like a joke. 'And here is a church where the worshipped-' and you were supposed to fill it in. Another example: 'Here is a school were children were taught-' Again, continue on. If you read through other peoples work, then you would see random words jumbled together, or lackluster 'Poetry'. This bothered me, as I'm a stickler for grammar, flow, and spelling.   Over all, the game is decent, but it felt like a joke in my opinion.

Damn! Best game ever! When I played, I had this feeling in my heart. I made the best stories I could write, I shared it with my friends ... Made a few limericks, too. Recommended 100%! Now, let me finish my stories ...
A lot of fun and very relaxing.
fill in the box writing simulator not even any good music
There is only three planet's to write on. and if your hunting for achievements you will never get them here.

With an atmosphere that will instantly hook you, Elegy for a Dead World is a delightfully novel way to approach creative writing. It really is just a series of writing prompts but between the sound and evocative environments, it's at once relaxing and creatively stimulating.  I do hope that more portals are opened over time; the devs have added more prompts to each existing world but additional environments would definitely be welcome.

Not recommended at its base steam price. I got this on Humble Bundle thankfully.  I like the idea of it. Honestly it's not bad, there's just not much content. Three worlds to explore and write your story about. As someone not much into writing I found it quite interesting to play through each one once but that's about the extent of my playthrough.

There is something so beautiful and simple about the concept behind this game. See images, create stories, share with others. While I feel there is work still to be done here (more worlds and an in-game spell-checker would be nice), there are few games quite like it and a lot of potential here.
